Not to be contrary, but I'd vote in favor of using powers-of-ten
consistent=
ly, and actually avoiding the powers-of-two units entirely.
So I'm in favor=
 of saying GB, TB rather than GiB, TiB, but also for 
switching to the prop=
er SI/ISO/IEEE/whoever-it-is definitions of 
those units.   I've heard enou=
gh puzzlement from less-technical 
folks over how one TB number and another=
 one can differ by ~10%, 
for the same quantity of content, that it just se=
ems safer to pin 
the units to decimal.     This way, too, non-technical pe=
ople can 
comprehend that a 250GB drive will actually store 250GB of
crawl =
content.  And this way the counter logic won't seem crazy
to people without=
 CS degrees: strictly increasing counts are nice :)
 
It puts the responsib=
ility of translating between 2^30/10^9 on the 
sysadmins, but they're the o=
nly folks who comprehend the difference
anyway, and at this point GNU tools=
 do the right thing, albeit awkwardly
(du --si).  Sticking to 2^30, but usi=
ng the GiB phrasing, would be 
pedantically correct but would only doubly c=
onfuse those who are prone 
to being confused...
 
Happy as ever to take a =
stand on the minor/unimportant issues of our day,
-Andy
